_prev_prog_3.Description: High Liner Foods has developed and administers a Process Safety Management Program as mandated by OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.119.  As part of the PSM Program, High Liner Foods has implemented strict preventative maintenance and operating procedures in compliance with the Process Safety Management program. Additionally, the facility has developed an Emergency Action Plan where the release of ammonia is specially covered in the plan and contains all required actions the facility will take in the event of a release.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

- Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

High Liner Foods is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety. This commitment is inherent to our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with our regulated process. It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible accidental releases of regulated substances. However, if such an accidental release does occur, we are coordinated with the Portsmouth City Fire Department and the Rockingham County Local Emergency Planning Committee for emergency response support.


- The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled

Presently Anhydrous Ammonia is the only RMP regulated substance present at this facility above a threshold quantity.  Ammonia is utilized as the primary cooling media in our closed-loop refrigeration system. The systemA?s purpose is to provide refrigeration and cold storage capabilities for High Liner Foods processing operations.  Due to the size and characteristics of our ammonia refrigeration system, as well as Process Safety Management (PSM) applicability, High Liner Foods is covered under Program 3 of the RMP regulations.

- Offsite Consequence Analysis 

The Worst Case Release Scenario(s) and the Alternative Release Scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario have been completed as stated in Section 2 and 3 of the RMP Submit text.

To evaluate both the worst case and alternative release scenarios, EPA's RMP Comp Hazardous Release software was utilized exclusively. The RMP Comp models are referenced in the RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance as an acceptable model for the release scenario mathematical approximation process.

As specified in the RMP Guidance, the worst case and alternate case release scenarios h

ave been calculated and the results of the calculations are documented in the High Liner Foods RMP Plan on file with the Plant Engineer at the facility.  Public and environmental receptors that could possibly be affected by the release scenarios were determined through the use of LANDVIEW VI mapping system software and US Census Bureau 2000 data. 

- The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

High Liner Foods has taken all necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set forth in 40 CFR Part 68.  To meet these necessary requirements High Liner Foods has implemented their Process Safety Management program through the written guidelines stated in the OSHA PSM Standard, 29 CFR 1910.119. 

- Accident History

There have been no ammonia related incidents at the High Liner Foods facility within the last five years that have resulted in on, or off site property damage, injuries or deaths.


THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

A process release would be detected by ammonia sensors located in the engine room, cold storage, and above the accumulators in the production area.  A A?hornA? evacuation signal is triggered and would sound throughout the facility.  An alarm is also activated at ADT.

In the event of a process release, ADT calls the facility maintenance department, which would in turn contact the Portsmouth Fire Station if any of the following conditions are present:

A?Upon investigating the incident, High Liner Foods determines that the release is severe enough to require response assistance; 
A?Reportable quantities of ammonia are released; and
A?A potential for fire exists (in this case, ADT directly notifies the Fire Department).

The Portsmouth Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC, or Portsmouth Fire Department) is trained and equipped to respond to ammonia releases at High Liner Foods.

- Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

High Liner Foods currently has no changes planned for t

he ammonia refrigeration process at this time.   However, the process will be subjected to periodic process hazard analysis reviews for the purpose of identifying potential hazards and implementing the necessary improvement to provide a safer system. High Liner Foods personnel will also periodically review all potential opportunities to improve the safety of our personnel, the surrounding community, and the ammonia refrigeration process.
